items.title: [ci] Unit tests fail on Mac
items.body:
Opening this issue from https://github.com/cpplint/cpplint/pull/149#issuecomment-646908591

While working on #149 , I found that the testing steps documented in [CONTRIBUTING.md](https://github.com/cpplint/cpplint/blob/develop/CONTRIBUTING.rst#development) seem to fail on Mac but pass on Linux. It's possible that the issue is about versions of some libraries and not operating system, but I have not been able to narrow that down.

## Reproducible Example

As of https://github.com/cpplint/cpplint/commit/010d807dfe4da782150a86817c60c73ecb7f1752, the most recent commit to `master` when I opened this issue, running this command:

```shell
pytest cpplint_unittest.py -k testInclude --no-cov
```

**Mac**

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7608904/85971714-8ae7ce80-b993-11ea-9e09-f2517e145341.png)

> ============ 1 failed, 3 passed, 191 deselected, 1 warning in 0.79s =============

**Linux**

```shell
docker run \
    --volume $(pwd):/usr/local/src/cpplint \
    -it continuumio/miniconda3 \
    /bin/bash

cd /usr/local/src/cpplint
pip install .[dev]

pytest cpplint_unittest.py -k testInclude --no-cov
```

> ============================ 4 passed, 191 deselected in 0.37 seconds ============================

## Possible Issue

With some print debugging, I found that on my Mac laptop the first test inside `testIncludeItsHeader()` produces this output

> /private/var/folders/xq/wktq4zdx4jd3qdpk34d28m940000gn/T/tmp57wr40fh/test/foo.cc should include its header file /private/var/folders/xq/wktq4zdx4jd3qdpk34d28m940000gn/T/tmp57wr40fh/test/foo.h [build/include] [5]'

but that the string expected has this (identical except the leading /private

> /var/folders/xq/wktq4zdx4jd3qdpk34d28m940000gn/T/tmp57wr40fh/test/foo.cc should include its header file /var/folders/xq/wktq4zdx4jd3qdpk34d28m940000gn/T/tmp57wr40fh/test/foo.h [build/include] [5]

I'm unsure how that leading `/private` is getting into the path and why the tests wouldn't work on Mac.

## Note for contributors

It's worth noting these two facts:

*  `cpplint` itself works without issue on my Mac laptop, so I think the problem here may be limited to the tests
* `cpplint` is [currently only tested on Linux environments in its continuous integration](https://github.com/cpplint/cpplint/blob/010d807dfe4da782150a86817c60c73ecb7f1752/.travis.yml)

items.title: Linux system headers not detected as system headers
items.body:
PR #133 swapped the dynamic system header detection from `<>` brackets to a hard coded list of names. This causes false positives in files with Linux specific includes. Unless I'm mistaken and files under `/usr/include` should not be classified as system headers.

test.h
```c++
// Copyright 2020 Open Networking Foundation
// SPDX-License-Identifier: Apache-2.0

#ifndef _PRIVATE_TMP_TEST_H_
#define _PRIVATE_TMP_TEST_H_

#include <net/ethernet.h>

#include <vector>

#include "absl/base/thread_annotations.h"

#endif  // _PRIVATE_TMP_TEST_H_
```

```bash
# cpplint test.h
test.h:9:  Found C++ system header after other system header. Should be: test.h, c system, c++ system, other.  [build/include_order] [4]
Done processing test.h
Total errors found: 1
```

items.title: Does `--headers` flag prevent to set default extensions?
items.body:
**Summary:**
Running `cpplint` with `--headers` flag seems to prevent default `extensions` values.

Is this a spec?


**Steps To Reproduce:**

* cpplint v1.4.4 

```
$ cat <<_EOF > main.cpp 
// Copyright 2020 foo
#include <main.h>
int main(int argc, char** argv) {
    char* h = "Hello";
    printf(h);
    return 0;
}
_EOF
$ cat <<_EOF > main.h
// Copyright 2020 foo#include <some_module/feature.h>
_EOF
$ ls | xargs cpplint --extensions=cpp --headers=h 2>&1 | grep -e "^main"
main.cpp:5:  Potential format string bug. Do printf("%s", h) instead.  [runtime/printf] [4]
main.h:0:  No #ifndef header guard found, suggested CPP variable is: _TMP_SAMPLE_MAIN_H_  [build/header_guard] [5]
```

When I run `cpplint` with `--exensions` and `--headers` , result looks good.

But when I run `cpplint` with only `--headers` flag actually prints below,
```
$ ls | xargs cpplint  --headers=h 2>&1 | grep -e "^main"
main.h:0:  No #ifndef header guard found, suggested CPP variable is: _TMP_SAMPLE_MAIN_H_  [build/header_guard] [5]
```
I expect both files are reported.
like set `--extensions=<default>,<appended by --headers>`

items.title: cpplint/cpplint.py false positive error for copy constructor
items.body:
According to C++ [specification](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/copy_constructor):
>A copy constructor of class T is a non-template constructor whose first parameter is T&‍, const T&‍, volatile T&‍, or const volatile T&‍, and either there are no other parameters, or the rest of the parameters all have default values.

The file `cpplint/cpplint.py` line number 3147 should be modified.

From: `Match(r'(const\s+)?%s(\s*<[^>]*>)?(\s+const)?\s*(?:<\w+>\s*)?&'`

To: `Match(r'((?:const|volatile|const\s+volatile|volatile\s+const)\s+)?%s(\s*<[^>]*>)?(\s+const)?\s*(?:<\w+>\s*)?&'`

To prevent false positive ccplint error:
> error cpplint: [runtime/explicit] Single-parameter constructors should be marked explicit.

When copy constructor is defined like:
`MyClass(volatile MyClass& rhs)`
`MyClass(const volatile MyClass& rhs);`
`MyClass(volatile const MyClass& rhs);`

items.title: spurious "should include its header file"
items.body:
If "Foo.h" exist and you have a file like this name Foo.cc
```c++
#include "Foo.h"
```
There is an error like this:
```
 ... Foo.cc should include its header file src/Foo.h  [build/include] [5]
```

This is because "Foo.h" is excluded from the `include_state` since it matches `_THIRD_PARTY_HEADERS_PATTERN`
In this case it should not be excluded because we are checking "Foo.cc".

```sh
gunzip fix-spurious-should-include-its-header-file.patch.gz
git apply fix-spurious-should-include-its-header-file.patch
```
[fix-spurious-should-include-its-header-file.patch.gz](https://github.com/cpplint/cpplint/files/2972639/fix-spurious-should-include-its-header-file.patch.gz)

patch tested with 1e7ecd3e18674784cdad34918b14d7f178bb81e7

items.title: Non-explicit copy construtors
items.body:
CPPLint warns about non-explicit copy constructors which makes no sense as implicitly generated copy constructors are non-explicit as well (https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/copy_constructor#Implicitly-declared_copy_constructor).

Example:

```
struct Foo {
  /// Copy constructor.
  Foo(const Foo & other)
  : member(other.member) {}
  int member;
}
```

yields:

```
- containers.cpplint runtime/explicit [5]
  <<< failure message
    Single-parameter constructors should be marked explicit.
  >>>

```
Is there a way to configure this behavior?

items.title: Order of includes error for 3rd party libraries (reopened)
items.body:
(reopening issue #7 because it was closed without resolution)
The following example snippet produces "Found C system header after C++ system header...[build/include_order]".

```cpp
#include <vector>

#include <gtest/gtest.h>
```
The problem goes away if the angle brackets are replaced by quotes.
I guess the script assumes the angle brackets only for C/C++ system and standard library headers.

items.title: Issue with 16 bit representation of unicode characters
items.body:
To reproduce:

```
#!/bin/bash

set -exuo pipefail

PYTHON_TAG_TO_CHECK=v2.7.4
PYTHON_UCS2="${PWD}/cpython/python_v2.7.10_ucs2"
PYTHON_UCS4="${PWD}/cpython/python_v2.7.10_ucs4"
NJOBS=16

git clone https://github.com/python/cpython.git
cd cpython
git checkout $PYTHON_TAG_TO_CHECK


mkdir ${PYTHON_UCS2}
mkdir ${PYTHON_UCS4}


test_with_cpp_lint() {
	local CMD="${1}/bin/python2.7 cpplint.py --filter=-build/header_guard,-legal/copyright initial_value_problem.h 2>&1"
	local output="$(eval ${CMD})"
	echo "${output}"
}

test_unicode_size() {
	if [ $(cat pyconfig.h | grep -cE "^\#define Py_UNICODE_SIZE $1$") -ne 1 ]; then
		echo "Py_UNICODE_SIZE ASSERTION FAILED"
		exit 1
			fi
}

check_assertion(){
    if [[ "$OUTPUT" != "$EXPECTED_OUTPUT" ]]; then
        echo "OUTPUT ASSERTION FAILED"
        exit
    fi
}


wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/google/styleguide/gh-pages/cpplint/cpplint.py

# The motivation of the excercise (Line 18)
wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/RobotLocomotion/drake/b6ff34893b83430c79043d0b6c29e00b8c04de52/systems/analysis/initial_value_problem.h

# The default is ucs2
# https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/1ce4e5bee6df476836f799456f2caf77cd13dc97/configure#L1473
./configure --prefix="${PYTHON_UCS2}" && make -j$NJOBS && make install
test_unicode_size 2

OUTPUT="$(test_with_cpp_lint $PYTHON_UCS2)"
EXPECTED_OUTPUT="$(cat << ENDOFTEXT
initial_value_problem.h:18:  Lines should be <= 80 characters long  [whitespace/line_length] [2]
initial_value_problem.h:19:  Lines should be <= 80 characters long  [whitespace/line_length] [2]
Done processing initial_value_problem.h
Total errors found: 2
ENDOFTEXT
)"
check_assertion

# Checking with --enable-unicode=ucs4
./configure --prefix="${PYTHON_UCS4}" --enable-unicode=ucs4 && make -j$NJOBS && make install
test_unicode_size 4

OUTPUT="$(test_with_cpp_lint $PYTHON_UCS4)"
EXPECTED_OUTPUT="$(cat << ENDOFTEXT

Total errors found: 0
ENDOFTEXT
)"
check_assertion

exit 0
```

items.title: Stream arguments passed by reference
items.body:
Non-const reference arguments for functions are violation of the guideline.
For output arguments, the pointers are requested,
but passing streams with pointers is awkward.

``` cpp
void Print(std::ostream* out) { (*out) << "text"; }
Print(&std::cout);
```

vs.

``` cpp
void Print(std::ostream& out) { out << "text"; }
Print(std::cout);
```

Cpplint only excuses streams by reference on overloading the `operator<<`.
It would also be helpful to completely exclude streams from the rule of pass variable only by const reference.
